reviewText: If you wondering the other is Contact(1997) starring Jodie Foster, but you can read my review there if you want to know why.  Besides being a Robin Williams fan, this movie was great even if he wasn't in it.  The visual  effects are incredible(it was nominated for two Oscars for them) and the  picture it creates of the afterlife is one I have never imagined.  I  especially like the explanation of what happens to suicides, which if  you're further interested in that or any other "theory" in this  movie you can read MUCH more in detail in the book version by Robert  Matheson.  The movie is much different from the book, but also much better.  The plot includes a lot about before he and she goes to heaven and hell.  Personally, this movie has one of the greatest beginnings and endings I  have ever seen.

One of the most imaginative films you'll ever watch. It reminds me of the Wizard of Oz, Tron, or The Neverending Story. Extremely bold. Is this what happens when you die? Who the hell knows (no pun intended), however it is a touching story that frames the most important moments in our lives in a storybook that is the human experience. Love, loss, pain, devotion, and transcendence.  Not recommended for cynics, hardcore religious fundamentalists, but to people with an open mind.

Also recommended: Ghost, Contact, Always, Resurrection (with Ellen Burstyn)

Robin Williams excels in this film. A brief synopsis Robin is a physician who has a wonderful life until his children die in a car accident. His wife whom he loves very much is unable to handle their death and ultimately commits suicide. Robin eventually dies and is transported to heaven , he encounters many people he met in his life including his dead son. His one hope is to see his wife again but is told that since she killed herself she is in a special place where she can never leave.  Still determined to see her, his guide takes him there, where he travels through limbo (children people floating), purgatory (multitude of faces in darkness voicing their sins) and to hell itself ! He encounters his lost wife who is living in their earthly house which is decrepit and dark, she perseverates on her circumstances and will not leave but he convinces her to do so. What makes this movie special is not the special effects which are great but the inclusion of eclectic religious dogma. The ending is wonderful , which focuses on the love we should have for each other and the love that God has for us.

Awe-inspiring.  Behold what Robin Williams at his finest, a sterling support cast led by the heart-breaking Annabella Sciorra, and a palette of mind-bending special effects can do.  Visions of a wet-paint heaven and an insidious hell I will never forget--Dante's Inferno wasn't this vivid.  I first saw this film in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, and wondered what the Spanish-speaking audience made of it.  As for me, I've watched it a number of times since, and even though at points it's pretty grueling, in the end it's a piece of cinematic redemption.  It's film victories like this that justify the whole writhing, whining, clichd mess that Hollywood has become--could there still be hope for the human race via the old "silver screen?"

This movie has the evocative power of a lucid dream.  If you have ever dreamed of a loved one who has died, then I think this movie will speak to you.  If you believe in heaven and hell, I think you will have a helluva heavenly ride. Robin Williams tones down his comic delivery and his dramatic chops are at the top of his game. This movie is my favorite, among his many excellent serious turns. The art direction is stunning. The entire cast, including Cuba Gooding, Jr., and Max Von Sydow take the abstract premise with the confident commitment of real artists.

4**** for graphic art, for the performances, but not for the script.  (Someone else here called it "an interesting experiment") and I agree.  This movie "idea" was a good one but it did little to clarify a "consciousness" after-death.  And,, we forget that "soul-mate" does not exist.  It is an idea and an ideal that exist in our culture as a principle to practice: it means that one has found a person that they like a whole lot and find them highly tolerable and those feelings appear to be real and permanent.  Okay: so now you can see how I looked at the movie and analyzed what I saw.  The subject grabbed me mentally so it ceased to be entertainment and I watched it to see how they ''treated'' the subject of "life" after death.

I love Robin Williams' talent.  And I will look at a few more performances of his work before I leave his front-porch-(page) here on Amazon.

I cannot say I would recommend the movie, certainly not for a fee (I paid $3.99 for the HD version).  Still, I enjoyed watching Robin Williams: I pray his soul is at peace.

One of my favorite Robin Williams movies. Robin is very serious in this movie and plays his character so well. The movie has several Christian themes including suicide, purgatory, Heaven, hell and the "answer" to "do animals go to Heaven?" Robin Williams made this movie after he switched his religious affiliation with Catholicism to Episcopal. One of the reasons Robin Williams gave for leaving the Catholic Church was that being an Episcopalian was twice as much fun and had half the guilt. The movie does cover Catholicism's belief that people who commit suicide cannot go to Heaven, and in this film Robin Williams, after he dies and goes to Heaven, chooses to leave Heaven and join his wife (a suicide victim) in purgatory.
It is a love story but with some unexpected twists and turns. You will love the ending!

Quickie Review:

Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert once gave this movie two enthusiastic thumbs up. But if you go back and watch their review you'll notice they avoid talking about the script, editing, and story and focus solely on the visuals. Well, there's a reason for that.

I'm sorry, but with all due respect to the immensely talented and sorely missed Siskel, Ebert, and Williams, this movie is awful. It is visually stunning and so very creative, but that does not make it a good MOVIE. Not in this form. It has some interesting ideas, but the finished product fails to deliver on nearly every one of them, taking easy outs and weakly wrapping it all in a pretty bow. It groans under its own self importance and lacks the muscle to hold it all in place. When I watched it recently I was astounded to find that the picture I once held in such high regard when I was a teenager was actually a jumbled mess rife with cornball cliches barely hidden beneath a thin veneer of pretty eye-candy. The editing was atrocious, the story was a first draft amateur mess that excused its flaws by barely being one step above "it's all just a dream." The only redeeming factors are the visuals and Williams' acting. He owned every frame, every moment. But let's be honest here, you could get the most talented actor in the world to play out an episode of Honey Boo Boo and that wouldn't make it Shakespeare.

Individual scenes, when taken alone and out of context of the movie, are brilliant. As short films in an anthology they may have worked, but strung together the way they were and paced the way they were they come across less like an actual movie and more like someone trying to trick the audience into mistaking a high school student's short story as an epic masterpiece.

In the end, the reason this movie was most hard to watch was to see such effort, such craft, being wasted on such a terrible screenplay and burdened by the director's misguided need to play at making an "art house picture."

This movie is without a doubt one of Robin Williams best movies. It is VERY intense, very serious and has amazing special effects and acting. After the untimely deaths of both of his children, Chris's (Robin) wife is distraught and not long after, Chris is killed in a traffic accident, leading him to go to Heaven. After this, he discovers his wife killed herself and goes to Hell. The movie is about how Robin's character travels to Hell to try and save her from the demise as a suicide victim. It's very good, and the trailer and summary doesn't do it justice. It will be worth your money.

Some have not enjoyed this film because it takes an ethereal, complex story concept and makes it both enjoyable and meaningful on an everyday level. The rich script by Richard Matheson and even-handed performance by Robin Williams worked well for me. It's a story that is really about *something* for a change, not just another mindless fantasy or action romp, although it has elements of those things, but done with imagination, artistry and restraint.

This is a tour de force performance by Robin Williams. It is made all the more poignant because the film's gist is that he has to save his wife from hell because she killed herself. In light of his own suicide, to see him saving someone else is almost a shattering experience. I did cry watching it.

The after life is splendidly recreated with every imaginative leap one could possibly make. On the box you see a dog by his side and that is the dog who died some years before his character died. That hit me very forcibly too. I saw this film originally in the movie theater when it came out in 1991. I was a fan of it then and I recollect most people were not.

My opinion has not changed in the intervening years. I could have stood a lighter hand on the music perhaps but that's just a quibble. After I initially saw the film I tried to read the novel. It was written in the 1950s by Richard Mathieson. I only got part way through it but the sheer imagination of the movie was just not there on the written page. Or perhaps it was that Robin Williams was not on the written page. It is hard to believe that a guy who could act such a serious part was also a world class stand up comic. He does manage to deliver a comic line near the end that I can't imagine any other actor pulling off given that he was inside of this serious script. You really need to see him in this if you have never seen this film before.  Bring a kleenex with you.

This movie is, to me, one of Robin Williams greatest features.  From the story line to the visual art graphics, to the cast and the directing, it is pure brilliance.  It is a believable, spiritual, mystical movie.  One that I can say, w/o a doubt, is a true type of story.  Cubba Gooding was the perfect choice to have as one of the main characters.  He and Robin both were so convincing, funny (of course) but also very serious.  The other cast members also added so much depth to the story.  Robin made this movie so believable, that even skeptics would have to reconsider their logic regarding the afterlife and reincarnation.  What Dreams May Come taps into the realm of Twin Flames (true soul mates) and does a fantastic job of explaining what it is like to be one.  In fact, this is a movie that could explain much to someone who is going through a spiritual  awaking, right now, and is looking for some type of validation or answers to their questions on the topic of Twin Flames/Soul Mates.  I could watch this movie over and over and never get bored.  Just with the colors of the art, this movie makes an impact.
Pure Brilliance, entertaining, and also very believable as to what is going on in the world of an awakening.  Highly recommend to all...even the skeptics.  I feel this movie may change their perspective on this subject.  With Robin starring in this one, this movie really could be the one to change a skeptics mind on the afterlife and soul mates.

I re-watched this recently and I was struck by how well it has held up in the many years since I've seen this last. It is still as gorgeous and mindblowing as when I first saw it on the screen. The special effects, especially the painterly, Impressionistic treatment of the afterlife still takes my breath away. The fantasy like sequences, even the depictions of Hell are unforgettable. The story is just as haunting, even more so with Robin Williams' death. I remember thinking a long time ago how unusually romantic and soulful his performance was since I was used to seeing him in so many comedic roles. Sciorra looks even lovelier and her performance still poignant. This movie is such a treasure, such a classic. I know I will watch it again multiple times in the future and I'm sure I will marvel at something new each time.
Loved it in the theater, loved it more the second, third, fourth and fifth times at home.  Keep your tissues nearby.

This is a deeply emotional and dramatic look at death and the possibility of life after death.  One of Robin Williams' best dramatic performances, and definitely one of his classics.  This look at life after death is very philosophical, and is appropriate for people of every belief.  It is not specific to a specific doctrine, or, I would say, any doctrine at all.  Instead it takes a look at the possibility, and incorporates aspects of almost every major system of belief within that realm of possibility.  What it does really well is show people in many different forms coming to grips with death and its inevitability, and how that affects us all.  It is a great story about family, true and unconditional love, and unbreakable bonds that are created in these relationships.  Anyone who speculates on life after death will find this interesting and satisfying.

THE FILM: WHAT DREAMS MAY COME is a visual feast (especially for 1998) that explores some weighty themes, but ultimately feels artificial and thinly painted. Robin Williams is Chris Nielsen, a doctor who suffers a great tragedy and ultimately is taken by fate as well. While in the afterlife, he goes on a journey to reunite himself with his wife. First of all, let me say that I don't subscribe to a belief in an afterlife, but the fact that the movie treats it as an objective thing wasn't really a problem for me. What was a problem was that the whole story was set up so quickly that the core relationship you're supposed to care about wasn't believable. Sure, the screenwriter covered themselves by having Chris and his wife (Annabella Sciorra) be "soulmates," but this felt like a cop-out from actually doing some character development and building a believable relationship. However, the sentiment expressed by Chris' journey is an understandable one. It tells the story of a man who literally goes to hell and back just to be with the one he loves. Aside from that, the best part of the movie is the visual flair with which the afterlife is realized. One of Chris' passions is painting, and his early experiences there are very much painting-like. This film won the Academy Award for Best Visual Effects in 1999, and from what I could tell, it was definitely deserved. The effects weren't necessarily realistic, but they were impressionistic and artistic. On the downside, the metaphysical content and ideas are practically shoved down the viewers throats. There are many conversations laden with language that's supposed to sound like it's important, but the story never really lives up to these lofty ideas. Also, when you create a fantasy world there are often rules established to that everything isn't pure chaos. Here, there are some rules established but the film doesn't stick to them. At times, it's unclear how the afterlife works, which could be confusing to some people (assuming they even believe in such a thing). Overall, this is a very spiritual film that aspires to greatness, but is only ok. Robin Williams and the rest of the cast give excellent performances, but the visuals only serve to paint over the cracks in the story.

THE DISC: The film is very beautiful to look at, and it is reproduced wonderfully here on Blu-ray. There are also a number of extra features which are great supplements to the film. The first of these is an alternate ending that actually is significantly different than the one used for theaters. The next is a 15 minute featurette that has interviews with the cast and crew about the production and basic information about their characters. While it was nice to have this, it felt like more of a fluff piece than something that really delves into the meaning of the film. The last featurette is a five-minute exploration on the visual effects. Being that this film was highly dependent on the visual effects, I would have expected more, but it was nice to see how some of the shots were created. Rounding things out is a feature-length audio commentary by the director, Vincent Ward, and two theatrical trailers.

OVERALL: This isn't one of Robin Williams' best films, but the visual effects and core sentiment expressed make it worthy of viewing. There is also a decent amount of extras, for people who enjoy supplementary material. It's not an essential purchase, except maybe for die-hard Robin Williams fans or people who like very spiritual stories.

The first part of the movie zooms by without developing any of the characters so you I didn't have much investment in who lives or dies and I couldn't really relate to anyone.  Their depiction and concept of Heaven and Hell was interesting. The storyline sounded interesting; !st Robin William's children die in an accident and he and his wife are devastated, then Robin, himself dies in another accident and his wife is so depressed after losing her whole family that she commits suicide. In the movie, Robin and the children go to Heaven but since suicide is a sin, his wife goes to Hell.  If you think this is a spoiler, you would be wrong; this all happens in a very short time after the movie starts. The rest of the movie is focused on Robin trying to get his wife out of Hell and into Heaven. If it had been done differently, I think it could have been a really good movie but for me it dragged on, and I almost fell asleep, in fact, I may have dozed off a couple of times. I like movies I don't want to end; this one, I couldn't wait for it to end. I have read somewhere that this movie is a sleeper and if you watch it over and over you will get it, more, and understand it better and you will see that it is really a very good movie, however; I can't bring myself to sit through it again but if you are game to find out then this is the movie for you.

What Dreams May Come. This movie showcases Robin Williams acting skills quite well. It is a story of a loving family that is struck twice by death,first the couple's two children. Four years later, the husband is killed in a massive car crash. The movie shows Chris (Robin Williams), the husband, going to Heaven. While exploring his heaven he finds that his wife has comitted suicide.

The rest of the movie shows Chris discovering his children and a long time mentor as he explores Heaven and searchs Hell for Annie, his wife. This is Robin  Williams acting in a Drama. It is not full of laughs, but it is not devoid of humor.

If you are a Robin Williams fan or simply like romantic stories about going to or being in Heaven, this is a movie to see. It is similar in tone to Patch Adams or One Hour Photo. If you are looking for a Laughfest,try watching something else.

May Robin Williams rest in peace.

This is a beautiful film in every way, with an unforgettable performance by Robin Williams. Now that Williams has departed the earth, it is even more poignant to see his gentle but fiercely loving portrayals in this movie and in the film World's Greatest Dad.  In his life and as an actor, Robin's great heart shown through his every action, and that is never more vividly shown than in the roles he played in these two films.  His eyes reveal a heartfelt love touched with sadness, conveying to the audience a depth of emotion that goes far beyond acting. You get the feeling you are seeing the real Robin Williams, beneath his often-worn clown mask. What Dreams May Come is an educational film about the afterlife, from a book by Richard Matheson. It is based on numerous reports of near-death experiencers, who tell us that death is merely a transition from one world into another and that life continues on eternally. But most especially, in this film we learn that love transcends all dimensions and truly is the most powerful force in the universe.  Robin Williams and the love, laughter (and tears) he contributed to the world in his short life will live on--in his films and in our hearts.

This final film in my marathon I saved for the last because it is my favorite of all his movies.  Having grown up with Robin Williams, it's hard to believe he won't be there to crack another joke for us tomorrow, but I thank him for everything he's given to us, his adoring public.  I know suicide is a sin in Christianity, a theme that this movie (and novel) is based on in part, but still I'd like to think he wasn't at fault and it was his sickness that took over for that one second that really counted.  Or, that Heaven will forgive someone whose energy sped through several lifetimes in one, and just got tired.

I'm tearing up as I write this review because this is a really moving story, not only because I want to believe that Robin Williams found the peace and happiness he couldn't find with the living, but because it's about hope, and true love and redemption -- all really heavy themes -- played against a beautiful backdrop that is like a vibrant, living oil painting.

This is pure eye candy for visual thinkers like me, where a picture speaks a thousand words.  It's also very romantic when you watch a man dive into the unthinkable to find his one true love and save her.

Though every character is technically "on the other side" it's a happy ending when you think everyone who has ever touched your life will be waiting for you when you get there.

I'd like to believe that Mr. Williams' Heaven is exactly as he imagined it and when the rest of us catch up, he'll still be there to crack us another joke.

While certainly a visually stunning film; it's the storyline that grips me. None of us definitely know what the hereafter may hold. Certainly a broad variety of faith-based beliefs offer their points of view. The uncertainty of what dreams may come was the crux of Hamlet's soliloquy (the title is derived from one of its lines) and this film poignantly weaves the "what ifs" as an offering for viewers to ponder. I found the whole context to be ultimately uplifting despite the heartache that goes hand in hand with act of departing, those coping with the departures, and what the dearly departed encounter. My hope is that what comes next is a spectacular journey to another realm brimming over with infinite possibilities. I viewed it when first released in theatres, again when I've seen it on TV, and purchased it this week after Williams' passing knowing it was how I wanted to reflect upon his boundless talents.

I usually don't write film reviews, but with the passing of Robin Williams, I felt a need to express some feelings for the man and the actor who I truly adored.
I remembered when I first saw the trailer for the movie, I was blown away. It felt like living in a Monet painting. I had never truly seen anything like it before.
To think that this film was made over 15 years ago, yet the visual effects still look great today is a testament to its achievement.

**Minor spoiler alert**
To the film itself - the premise is that Robin Williams' character is involved in an accident and dies. Because he doesn't want to leave his wife and his family, his spirit lingers on to look after her. His guardian angel in the afterlife is played by Cuba Gooding Jr., who guides him and eases his transition into the afterlife. This part of the movie is still light-hearted, very colorful, very serene. This is the most visually beautiful part of the movie. However, things turn for the worse when Williams' wife can't bear his loss any longer, and takes her own life. Suicide is one of the ultimate sins, so instead of joining Williams, her spirit must go to Hell. The story of the movie is Williams' journey to rescue his wife's spirit and allow her to join him in Heaven, which is an almost impossible task considering such a feat has never been accomplished before. In the basic sense, this is a story of how Love can triumph over anything.

This movie might not be one of Robin's best acting, but it does belong in your collection if you want something visually beautiful, and if you're a fan of his. It's one of those films, like "The Cell," whose visuals will always stick with you and withstand the test of time.

Highly Recommended!

I watched this movie after hearing the news of Robin Williams' suicide. It obviously made it all the more poignant, and, as I'd already been weeping, I cried through much of the film. I had to wonder how much of this haunting story and its many questions about life, death, life-after-death, suicide and redemption resonated in William's sorely tormented mind at the time he took his own life.

The movie itself is a visually wonderful, often painfully beautifully, often tragically diabolical, much as in a Bosch grotesque yet fantastical image. It is a fine cast, although the ending is a bit perturbingly abrupt/too clean cut.

I will watch it again, but probably not for quite some time. It's a lot of emotions to handle, maybe too many, but though-provoking and memorable.

"What Dreams May Come" is not only my favorite Robin Williams movie, but it is also my favorite film of all-time. I saw this film 5 times in the theatre when it came out back in 1998. It touched me so deeply on so many different levels, and it still does. It's the most beautiful love story I have ever seen on film, both of romantic love and the love of family. The movie also speaks to me spiritually, as it explores quite wonderfully the "what-if" possibilities of the afterlife. This film always takes me on the most amazing journey every time I watch it. Robin Williams' heartfelt performance is nothing short of outstanding, as are the performances of Annabella Sciorra, Cuba Gooding Jr., and Max Von Sydow. Vincent Ward's direction is superb. And the visuals of the afterlife in this film, both Heaven and Hell....those magnificent, Oscar-winning visuals...."What Dreams May Come", even now, still stands for me as the most breathtakingly beautiful-looking film I have ever seen. And the ending of this movie....simply perfect.

Back in 1998, "What Dreams May Come", probably because of it's heavy subject matter, was not well-received on its initial release, despite that Visual Effects Oscar (and some very high praise from Siskel & Ebert, two of the very few critics who *did* recognize the film's greatness at the time). But I'm so glad to see that the passing of time has been very kind to "What Dreams May Come", with more and more people discovering this wonderful film, and not only discovering it, but understanding it, appreciating it, and being moved by it. And despite the terrible, heartbreaking tragedy of losing Robin Williams, "What Dreams May Come", as well as Robin's magnificent performance in it, now takes on a whole new poignancy.

I am grateful to know that people are now turning to "What Dreams May Come" in droves to remember Robin Williams by, as evidenced by the film's new resurgence in popularity. Of course people are watching his other great films too. So am I. For great bellylaughs, Robin's hilarious voicework in "Aladdin" and "Robots" will do very nicely. "Good Morning Vietnam" and "Awakenings" are also great Robin Williams movies. But "What Dreams May Come", in particular, seems to be the people's #1 choice of the man's film work at the moment, and for this I am very, very happy.

I think that is all I can say. I love Robin Williams, and I love "What Dreams May Come". God bless you, Robin. Thank you for all the joy that you gave us. Be at peace.

This outstanding movie is an emotional home run.  A grand slam that clears the bases bringing home loss, pain, grief, and joy. Fully expressed and realized in the surprising visuals (Ellen M. Somers), magnificent photography (Eduardo Serra) and carried throughout with an intoxicating musical score (Michael Kamen and The London Metropolitan Orchestra) that hauntingly swells with intensity. Vincent Ward impeccably directs a visual feast portrayed through paintings.  They literally come to life throughout the film placing the viewer into another dimension all within the changes of Chris Nielsen (Robin Williams) and perfectly ethereal Annie's (Annabella Sciorra) realities.

The two meet quite suddenly while vacationing and remarkably find that they are truly soulmates.  They may not fully realize its beauty at this venture but as time passes the wonder becomes more and more evident.  A lifetime together is altogether inevitable as they marry, have two children and begin a lovely family life.  What is immediately sorrowful is the tragic accident that takes the lives of their children and throws the couple into gut-wrenching grief.

The story jumps ahead four years while the pain of loss is taking any life from the brilliantly artistic Annie.  Her paintings (done by Stephen Hannock) are being affected and her mind is becoming more distraught.  It is then that a freak accident happens again and Chris dies.  She is left alone, her family gone and also her own will to live.  From this moribund beginning comes a fantastic living tale of a husband's passionate and overwhelming love for his wife driving him through heaven and hell to find her.

Chris' journey begins in a heaven that he has created for himself but seen through the paintings of Annie.  An angel guide, Albert (Cuba Gooding Jr.), is there to aid him in realizing that he has died and must go on separately.  His creation is awash in vibrant color with an identifiable use of the color blue from the start of the film.  What he sees and makes true for himself is what Annie creates or has created.  The look at morality is done without a major pull onto any certain religion so it can astoundingly stretch the boundaries.  It's quite another view of the afterlife that is as imaginarily beautiful in its heaven as it is as boldly macabre in its hell.

Annie takes her own life.  Albert gives this information to Chris who becomes desperate to save his wife from the hell she has also created.  The movie treats the act of suicide very differently than the way it may be viewed by some, with more of a compassionate tone.  As freeing as Chris' reality may be, Annie's is quite deliberately confining.  The visuals and the sets come to life and seduce the viewer into a horrifically confused state of mind.  The Tracker (Max Von Sydow) takes Chris to places where no other has ever gone, as nobody has ever been brought back from this terrifying place.  Annie does not know him here, she has slipped into her mind and birthed a place of repetitive torture.

Based on the novel by Richard Matheson with a masterful screenplay by Ron Bass, the story jumps off the screen and truly captivates.  A very active movie that effectually works all the way around, digging deep to portray this transcendent love between husband and wife.

*Enveloping every part of myself concerning the recent happening to Robin Williams, along with the deepest sorrow and compassion for his family: May this in some remote way honor his wonderful memory. 8/2014

Virtually unwatchable, "What Dreams May Come" (1998) is pure, unmitigated schmaltz that rings hollow. Oscar-winning visuals only emphasize the misguided banality  a pale shadow of Richard Matheson's metaphysical novel. For all his comedic gifts, Robin Williams utterly fails at solemnity. And Max von Sydow's presence is a terrible thing to waste.

Great version of what happens after death and suicide and the possibilities of redemption through love and a soul-mate--and the scenes of hell are amazing ! As usual Robin Williams rocks as a brilliant, funny guy -- this time with a take on the afterlife with just enough humor in it to keep the subject matter not-too- heavy.  Special effects star in this movie, from a world in which all surfaces are paint to the deep grey of a suicide's hell. I saw this movie when it first came out and I thought it was visually stunning, emotionally heart plucking, philosophically uplifting and jammed with authentic and true acting. I got the chance to see the last forty minutes again on TV just a few minutes ago and my initial reaction hadn't changed. I remember the movie being bashed and laughed at and decided to come on Amazon to see if people had changed their minds. Four stars and 600 plus ratings later, I was happy to see that people had. In these difficult times when we lose loved one way too often, this movie is hope-filled and a balm against such loss. More than that, it is a testament to the power of love. There are a few sayings about love: that it is forever and can overcome any obstacle. This movie brings both to light. I applaud the director, the cast and the crew. This has become a timeless classic for myself and many many others...

This film is a most fascinating depiction of the possible reality of life beyond this life. While I do not personally believe in an after life of any type of hell, I do see the truth of the hell people create for themselves and others on this planet now.
Jesus Christ himself said that "The kingdom of God is within you." It stands to reason that so is Hell.
My favorite scene is when Robin William's character finds his wife in her hell and tries to connect with her. The dialogue that comes out of his mouth is absolute truth!
In our world culture, men are taught not to feel anything that is less than wonderful.- with the exception of anger. The sad result is the frustration of inability to connect with others, especially the opposite sex, emotionally.
When Robin's character decides it's better to live in hell with the one he loves than live in heaven without her, he takes the plunge, the risk of being doomed to hell forever, only to find that that is the only way his wife can FEEL his love, which empowers her to come out of her hell.
Oh if every man could watch that film and wake up to the meaning and abiltiy to connect with others on an emotional level, they would find that they can leave hell and enter into heaven in their relationships.  Not everyone is willing, nor necessarily able, yet many could have a much different life experience if they learned the lessons that Robin's character was able to learn.
I could go on and on...... Excellent story. Very much true in the concepts depicted. Robin is an excellent actor. So are the others.

I've never read the book that this movie is based on, but I've read a synopis of it and they are WAY different. If you've read the book but haven't seen the movie, expect MAJOR changes in the movie. I highly recommend this movie to anyone with a loving family, anyone who has lost someone close to them, and anyone who loves sappy movies. What Dreams May Come is a really emotional love story... but not right away.  Quite the opposite in the beginning.  This part is about Robin Williams first losing his kids in a car accident, then losing himself in a separate car accident, and finally losing his wife to suicide.  Now that's what I call the ultimate depressing storyline!  However, it's not *entirely* devoted to sadness (hence the "love story" part).

What happens is that Robin Williams eventually arrives in what appears to be either someone's imagination with painted backgrounds, or heaven itself.  Robin Williams is easily the star of this movie and receives the most attention.  For a little while, Robin Williams appears to be here alone and finds himself exploring the curiosities of this unexplainable and high imaginative world, but soon he meets up with his deceased dog now as a younger pup, and another man (and later on, a shrink with important knowledge concerning people's fate).  We then learn Robin is actually in heaven and the paintings are part of his wifes drawings.  Interesting stuff.

As a viewer, you'll be totally caught up in the beautifully created backgrounds.  Nothing like I've ever seen in a movie, that's for sure.  The one segment with a bird flying above and soaring through painted skies is a highlight.

Unfortunately this movie isn't without a few minor flaws.  For one thing, I'm not crazy about the belief that those who commit suicide go somewhere else.  I don't believe this personally- that's why I don't like it.  However that's not the reason I'm lowering the overall rating to 4-stars.  It wouldn't be fair to lower the rating based on personal beliefs anyway.  It's how the beauty and adventure of the heavenly state we experience in the first half is exchanged for a slow-moving emotional journey to find Robin's wife in the second half.  A good chunk of this is, I'm afraid, quite boring (due to so many romantic and meaningful flashbacks between Robin and his wife).  But I suppose a second viewing might change my mind.

The ending is amazing though.  About the best way to wrap up these events.  Overall, a really well-made movie with a unique spin on the afterlife.  I'm warning you though- it CAN get really emotional on a few occasions, and if you're easily bored you've been warned about the second half.

This movie had some beautiful parts - mainly the art theme and beautiful coloring. But for me it wasn't believable mainly because of a lack of character development. The love story between Chris and Anna didn't draw me in. There just wasn't any chemistry between them in the beginning, and their love affair (i.e. their becoming "soul mates") happened too fast for me to feel like I witnessed or felt it happen. Then came their two kids who we were watching the funeral for just a few minutes after first meeting them. Again, very little character development. The deaths of the children should have caused me to feel the hurt and loss that Chris and Anna would feel as their parents. But, instead, it was very fairly unemotional for me because there was no chance for me to connect with them as characters. This movie could have been done so much better. It seems rushed and, well, carelessly put together. It is hard to follow and even borders on ridiculous at points.

The actors did a good job with what they were given to work with. Robin Williams, being the funny guy that he is, can sometimes be hard to believe in a romantic role. But, I've seen a couple of other movies of his where he was able to pull it off so I don't lay the blame on him. Annabella Sciorra's acting was fine as was Cuba Gooding Jr's (whose presence helped carry this movie along, in my opinion - - that is, until it was revealed who his character really was).

Having the children become other people in "heaven" just increased the distance I already felt from their characters. Finally, the end of the movie with the family reuniting in "heaven" brought the chaotic storyline to a close and I was able to smile because they were at least all together and it was over. All I can say is that I'm glad I didn't pay movie theatre prices to see this.

In every sense of the word, this is the most romantic movie I can remember. That does not mean it is all sentimental hugs and kisses. It delves darkly into isolation and longing, death and despair; like an extended romantic poem, it presents some intensely subjective visions of a man's relationship to others and to the natural and supernatural worlds. In fact, as director Vincent Ward admits near the end of an excellent commentary track, this is nothing less than a New Age reworking of the ancient legend of Orpheus, who descended into the deepest depths of Hades' realm in hope of finding his beloved wife and restoring her to life and light. In this movie, however, the husband dies first and then begins his quest to be reunited with his love.

Any review of this film--and any brief excerpt promoting it--must communicate a sense that it is visually dazzling, finding unprecedented techniques to create properly dreamlike visions of afterlife situations: The characters are immersed in settings vast and brilliant, inspired by a dozen painters from various eras of art history, brushstrokes and all. More surprising, perhaps, is the formidable acting of Annabella Sciorra and especially Robin Williams, communicating a whole palette of nuanced emotions in a noncomic role. (How could anyone complain of a lack of chemistry between them!) The movie's structure is unorthodox, with its strategically positioned, unexpectedly believable flashbacks, and throughout the journey, Michael Kamen's lush orchestral score sweeps us onward, adding hugely to the emotional experience. The surround sound is likewise spectacular.

The weak link, if any, is the script. At best, it is properly unpredictable and sometimes exquisitely crafted (as in Chris's eulogy at the funeral of his teenage son). At other times it becomes unnecessarily vulgar or takes a few steps toward pretentiousness, which means that some viewers may be pardoned for finding individual moments off-putting or vaguely silly. All the same, we feel a bit cheated when an occasional line is hard to hear clearly on first viewing--for instance, because of Max von Sydow's accent. Though his relatively brief performance as a rather grumpy spiritual "tracker" is too understated and matter-of-fact for my taste, old von Sydow does get one of the best moments, when he dramatically warns our hero that the real danger of Hell is not physical torment but losing one's sanity and, by implication, one's soul. And if this film succeeds in provoking some fresh thoughts and feelings about all our preconceptions regarding life after death, surely that in itself is a triumph.

As a bonus feature, the DVD includes an early, alternative version of the movie's final two scenes (with their postproduction aspects not fully polished). I have a slight preference for this original ending, though I might have left its last two minutes on the cutting-room floor. While it presents a different, more explicit, more complex picture of what lies ahead for the two soul mates, it does not drastically change the feeling or message of the movie. We might also recognize that the theatrically released ending, though sometimes dismissed as overly "cute," does a neater job of bringing the story full circle.

(There is one slight problem with the DVD, as both the trailers and the alternative ending have been vertically squeezed to an aspect ratio of nearly 3:1, making the actors appear fatter than they are. By contrast, the feature film is presented with an aspect ratio a bit narrower than the advertised 2.35:1, making us wonder whether the extreme left and right edges of the image have been chopped off.)

At a time when virtually every Hollywood product steals ideas from countless films that came before, _What Dreams May Come_ is genuinely original and unique, not to say profoundly beautiful. It may appeal to the same audience as other modern "love stronger than death" movies such as _Defending Your Life_ and _Just Like Heaven_, yet it is more serious and far more ambitious in its aims than those two. Connoisseurs of classic international cinema may observe some thematic connections with the works of Jean Cocteau, or may note that Vincent Ward and his team capture some of Powell and Pressburger's creative excitement about exploiting Technicolor in the service of a surreal spirit. More simply, _What Dreams May Come_ does what movies ought to do but rarely achieve: instead of merely telling a story, it helps us see the world in a new way, through *moving* visual images that no other medium could so effectively present.

[Now can someone please explain why the closing credits include a credit for "Russian folk music research"?]

Whenever Robin Williams stars in a film that is out of the ordinary of his comedic roles, he shows what acting is about.  "What Dreams May Come" is one of the examples of Williams's diverse filmography that surpasses the humor he is so well know for.  The film focuses on how one handles grief and loss, but what is unique is how it is approached -- much like an artist's blank canvas.  As personal expressions are interpreted within the canvas in the form of colorful and emotional images, one realizes that the memories and the images can forever be embedded within the frame of a canvas.  For Williams's character Chris, that appears to be the case but not quite coincidental because his wife Annie (Annabella Sciorra) was an artist.  Chris and Annie's subject on the canvas is coming to terms with their children's death.

Through present events and flashbacks before the loss, Director Vincent Ward shows that Chris and Annie lived an average life.  Their life changes after their children's accident and the quick turn of events that have Chris, especially Annie struggling to overcome their grief.  Certain parts of the film may pay reminders to other films that depict characters encountering or about to encounter life changing moments, "It's A Wonderful Life," "City of Angels," "Heaven Can Wait," and "Meet Joe Black."  Indeed, all of these films possess a metaphysical quality, but "What Dreams May Come" may stand out from all of the above.  Chris appears to be in limbo between heaven and hell, and it is where he first ends up that looks like paradise - his wife's paintings, beautiful and celestial.  However, he is not alone in his journey and is accompanied by the first doctor that he had interned with, Albert (Cuba Gooding, Jr.).  And one wonders of the significance of each and every character or events that Chris experiences, which may make the viewer think beyond appearances.  Ward is very suggestive of the storyline that delves much deeper into the examination of natural order and choice and how it relates to how individuals deal with loss.

"What Dreams May Come" is thought provoking and questions may arise throughout the film and after.  So many words can describe the story being told within the film, but one phrase comes to mind, life is like a painting.

This movie has some very interesting concepts and a few interesting cinematic effects.  I guess that I'd characterize it more in the category of "chick flick" than anything else.  It shows emotion and relationships.  If you're in the mood for something like that, it's worth the view!  Don't come to it with expectation of anything intellectual or action-oriented.  Anyone with strong religious convictions will likely find it unsuitable--it doesn't really meet any church dogma that I'm familiar with.  Just sit back and watch it for fun and for the utterly unique storyline.

What dreams may come is a beautiful love story. The scenery is beautiful the special effects are out of this world. This is a must see for the romantic at heart. Its sad, funny, and one of my favorite Robin Williams serious roles. The whole cast is amazing.

I had originally bought this for my mother for her birthday, but I ended up watching it more than her!  The film is very existential, and it makes one think about life. For more information, I would watch a trailer of the movie on YouTube. I give this film 5 out of 5 stars.

I have watched this movie two times. The first time came at a particularly sad time in my life. It helped a lot.
The second time I watched it with friends. We all enjoyed it very much.
Finely crafted translation of sensitive and difficult to define issues into well understandable visual language.  The acting is superbly convincing.

Chris Nielsen (Williams) and Annie Collins (Sciorra) marry and have two children. They seem to enjoy their blissful success, but it doesn't last very long. Both of their children are killed in a car crash, and now Chris and Annie are more disconnected than ever. One year later, Chris himself is killed in a car accident, and he is sent to heaven. There, he discovers his power to create anything that is produced in his own mind. Albert (Gooding, Jr.), his longtime mentor, guides him through the process.

What Dreams May Come is a very beautiful film. Even if it's very different from the original novel (which I have never read, by the way), it does its job very well with its fantastic visuals. The heavenly landscapes created by the human mind are very creative: special effects are particularly stunning. The plot may be a little thin, but the most important elements in this film are the visuals. The acting is also satisfactory: Robin Williams plays yet another dramatic role without a hitch. He is completely convincing as a man who [almost] finds himself in harmony in heaven. Annabella Sciorra is lovely and memorable as Collins who is struggling to cope with her huge personal loss. Cuba Gooding Jr. gives a terrific performance as Albert: it's clear that he is enjoying himself with the role.

What Dreams May Come is not perfect, but it's still a beautiful film. I admire it for its stunning visuals and for its wonderful performances.

Grade: 8.7 out of 10

I saw this film in the theatre when it was first out, so my review is of the film and not the format (DVD, etc...)  If you ever get a chance to see this on a theatre screen, definitely go!

I had no real idea what I was in for with this film, but it is probably the most visually stunning film I've ever seen.  If you like art you will love this film just for the gorgeous art references.  It's unbelievably beautiful at times and darkly frightening at others.

The story is truly heartbreaking, but worth the journey.  All in all a cathartic experience (and isn't that one of the great outcomes of a fine film?) I don't know if I will ever watch this a second time, especially on a small screen (you know how everyone else loves your sunset photos but you can't bear to look at them because the real thing was so much more amazing and you don't want to ruin your memories?), but it's stayed with me all these years and I'm so glad I've seen it.

Although it is absolutely nothing like this in storyline, another film that feels similar to me in it's reality twisting creativity is The Time Bandits.  If you like The Time Bandits, or The Adventures of Baron Munchausen (huh, another Robin Williams film), you might want to give this a try.
Very pleased!!!! I have been looking for this movie for a while..It was one of the first movies my husband of 10 yrs and I watched together..Also a very smooth transaction.

This movie is very saccharine. Some of the visuals are nice to look at.
This is a VERY, VERY comforting and totalizing view of life/death/morality.
Robin Williams dramas tend to be...heavy-handed.

But I went to sleep before the film ended the last time I watched it. I was woken up by my wife kissing and hugging me, asking me "are you my soul mate?"

"Yes!"

So it made for a nice moment between us. For that, I'll give the film three stars.

I don't know what else I should have expected ... I mean, as if Hollywood is the expert on the metaphysical .. ha!  In fact before you watch it ask yourself if you got all the actors in Hollywood together with their feel-good reality-is-what-you-make-of-it mumbo jumbo to decide what the afterlife would be like what you'll come up with is probably this movie.  The ending has a twist in the last couple minutes that is just so typical of the kind of people who think that falling in love is better than being in love (ie - shallow people who aren't very good at maintaining relationships).  To someone like me who prizes wisdom above the torturous path to get wisdom, well ... let's just say that it seems those who don't probably have never gained wisdom in the first place and spend to much time romanticizing the way things were than appreciating what really happened and getting on with eternity.  In short, if that's what heaven is like (and I'm confident it isn't) then no wonder why so few people are interested in getting there.  Sad thing is ... I think most people think that's what it is and don't yet realize what a drag that kind of eternity would be.  IMO there is so much more to the universe and the rest of eternity than what's on this amazing little planet ... this life is just a stepping stone to get there, and well if I were to do a movie about what I think the afterlife is like ... it would blow your mind if you thought this movie came even moderately close.  It is said that when Steve Jobs died his last 3 words were "Oh Wow ... oh wow ... oh wow".  I don't know if that was due to what he was witnessing or a realization ... but regardless I think film could not come close to do justice to what the world beyond this one is really like, let alone the reality of what the purpose of our existence here really is about.

It has an ongoing subliminal influence that overcomes the gimmicky and sometimes off putting images.  Anyone who has suffered loss of a loved one to suicide or to a tragic accident will find a lot of comfort here, I think.  I love the idea that here on earth and in our afterlife, we are responsible for our own destiny and I love the idea that we can continue to help and celebrate our loved ones

If you are a hopeless romantic, or simply a fan of love stories, this is a movie for you.  Telling the story of a love which endures even unto death, and traverses the very landscape (or should I say "dreamscape") of Hell, "What Dreams May Come" was a wonderful film.

The film was stunningly vivid; watching it was like stepping into a dream.  While the creators of the film took much license when filming, "What Dreams May Come" nonetheless is capable of holding it's own against other films, as well as the book (of the same title) upon which it was based.  If you enjoy this movie, consider purchasing the book--I know that I did.

Perhaps the most beautiful and poignant love story ever written. It took me awhile to find, purchase and read an autographed first edition. Well worth it. The movie followes it somewhat closely, and does it well. I prefer the book. But the movie is a must see and own.

Wow. I seriously cannot believe that anyone would watch this theatrical abomination! The plot was so slow, everyone in it was a not-so-fantastic actor ), the dialoge was lame and the music was so loud I could barely hear anything else! Okay, so the special effects were cool, but that really doesn't make up for the bad acting and lack of plot. Also, the special effects were better suited for a children's fantasy movie, although the theme was very mature -- dealing with death, heaven, hell and suicide. It just left me shaking my head in confusion. And plus, the main character (Chris) was completely uncaring about his children, and more interested in his stupid dog and a TREE one minute, but then a loving, doting father. Honestly?!?! Talk about mixed messages. This really could have been an interesting story, the main idea was thought-provoking, but it was executed in such a haphazard manner. There were tons of holes in the plot, supposedly there are not ruled in heaven, and then suddenly there are. This could have been a good movie, but unfortunately it very fell short of my expectations.

Wonderful movie, but there's plenty out there on that and the DVD reviews cover that just fine.

Image quality is for the most part a substantial upgrade over the DVD, especially for the impressionist painting sequences, where you can really see the brush strokes and a just incredible level of detail. There are some later scenes which aren't quite as good, especially the flashback sequences with the son, but they were like that on the DVD. The parts that the PQ matters for are gorgeous. If you loved the look of this movie you WILL want this Blu Ray.

Didn't really notice improvements in the sound. It's still a 5.1 soundtrack, no better no worse as far as I could tell from a single viewing.

The alternate ending (the one from the Richard Matheson story the movie is a pretty dammed faithful adaptation of) is 16x9 in a 4x3 ratio box. So it takes up about a quarter of the screen. Granted was not very good video quality to begin with, but still an odd choice. You'd think it wouldn't have been that difficult to just set it to a full 16x9. But the PQ of it wouldn't have been any better.

The major special features are still there

Director's commentary
Making of Featurette
Visual Effects
Trailers

It doesn't seem to include the low res picts of some of the paintings that were included on the DVD, given the paucity of blu ray drive equipped computers, it's not much of a loss. I'm pretty sure a single frame capture from the blu ray would be higher rez.

This film is an absolute joy to watch. The artistic use of color and beautiful scenery alone would make it a fascinating view of the artist's impressions of heaven. That being said, the romantic story that holds it together works incredibly well. Robin Williams fits perfectly into this movie. He manages to convey the right sense of emotion for each scene, yet remaining capable of the occasional odd bits of humor. Everything just fits together so well in such an emotional masterpiece.

I have never read the book. That being said, having read some of Masterson's work and reading the differences between the film and book I can say this is probably a much more enjoyable movie for its genre. If they were to have been true to the book I'd imagine it would be much less of a beautiful love story, and much more of a metaphysical view of the afterlife.

Lately I've been on a Robin Williams kick, having enjoyed Bicentennial Man recently. I picked up this DVD and though the film tends to be maudlin at times, overall is quite a production! Philosophy: In my studies I had discovered that thought is greater than reality, and that you are not your arms, legs or brain, but you are you as a spiritual being. The film emphasized this without beating you over the head with its spiritual thought & inspiration, but was necessary to develop this concept for the film to make sense! Annie & Chris: Annie & Chris meet with the typical Hollywood "cute moment." They ram their boats into each other in Europe. Annie has claimed Switzerland in the name of Minnesota and Chris just claims her for his bride. We don't get a lot of character development here until well into the film. The flashback sequences are done well and are at times extremely emotional. Their life looks great until their children get killed in a car crash. Annie blames herself and goes into a deep depression which she never recovers. Mythology: There are ancient tales of the hero travelling into the depths of hell to recover his love. Even the gates of hell in the film had a large ship with the name Cerberus (the three headed dog, natch!) on front! The imagery of heaven and hell are well-presented. The crazy Raphaelian paintings; the upside-down cathedral; the heaven created that is actually made of paint! Crazy! Ending: The movie slam-punches grief until you can just cry with the anguish that Annie feels. The film tastefully covers the areas of suicide and never giving up. And even when you lose, you win (still trying to wrap my wits on this one). Movie critics have said that Robin Williams and Annabella Sciorra were not in tune in this film, but I beg to disagree. At times maudlin and heart-wrenching, the actors do indeed put their heart into their work and come out shining. DVD: Has an alternate ending which I'm glad was not in the final cut. The actual ending was more a message of hope that did not drag the story way out. The "making of" segment with a few words from the novelist Richard Matheson was also enjoyable. Recommended! Other Robin Williams Films: Bicentennial Man Mrs. Doubtfire [Blu-ray]

I bought this movie because I read the back of the box which belonged to my fiance's roommate. The summary got me hooked; I opened the case and it was empty, so I decided to get the movie here off of Amazon. I was really looking forward to watching it. It did have many good points in it, however it was missing the things that really connect the audience to what's happening in the movie. The most emotional part of the movie is when each of the characters loses a loved one, mainly the character played by Robin Williams . This is constructed well, but it comes too soon for the viewers to really have a connection to the loss; you don't learn more about each of the characters until later, after their death.
The characters were also unrelatable. They had likes, dislikes, jobs, wishes that were separated from the audience. They were generally good characters, but they didn't help the audience bond with them, which is a key element in any movie.
Overall, the movie was also really depressing. It had some high points, but those were too whimsical to make up for the low points. I wouldn't recommend it.
Though my fiance was crying at the end, so that's got to make up for something.

I read the book when it first came out and have re-read it thru the years, as it's one of my all time favorites.  I always thought it would make a wonderful movie and waited for years until this one finally came out in the late 90s....I was so excited when I heard that it was finally going to be made into a movie...until I saw the movie.  I don't believe I have ever been more disappointed in my life in a book-to-movie movie.

They took way too many liberties with regards to changes in the movie that it almost made it seem like a totally different story.  By killing off the children (which did not happen in the book) it made it seem like the grief Ann would have felt at losing Chris would not have been life shattering enough.  THEN they killed him off.  The point of the whole story was the closness between Chris and Ann...THEIR bond...which was stronger than anything else in their lives.  That was the point of the story.  And while I love Robin Williams, I felt that his portrayal of Chris bordered on silliness.  Hollywood even had to change Chris' profession...I guess him being a writer wasn't acceptable enough.....they made him a doctor.

To say I was highly disappointed in the movie is an understatement.  I don't blame Richard Matheson for being disappointed as well..... " I was disappointed in it, because it changed a good deal of my story, and I thought by their desire to have the two children die before him - they did that because they felt that if she committed suicide and left children behind, the audience would not like her, which, you know, may or may not be true - but it made for terrible complications, I thought, especially when they decided not even to identify them in the afterlife but to have them disguised as various other people." Richard Matheson - quote.

Well, said Richard.  I guess Hollywood felt that they knew more about your book than you did.  Evidently not because the movie, in my opinion, was AWFUL!!!!! I do give credit to special effects, though......without them, the movie was a disaster.

FORGET THE MOVIE..........READ THE BOOK!!!!

Aside from traditional teachings about heaven or hell, this movie explores possibilities beyond what most of us ever consider feasible and therefore we tend to disregard this kind of thinking before we acknowledge the beauty and transcending wonder of just might be the best movie to define the kind of love most of us really, honestly desire to be part of - both sides of such a depth of loving another person. Anabella Sciorra is a an absolutely beautiful woman who was able to find her prince charming fairy tale type partner and then through accidental death loses him and finds herself unable to get past the grieving over her loss. Robin Williams is the character married to Anabella's character, and the film takes us through several channels of him discovering heaven to be quite different than he anticipated. Then this fantastic adventure of imagination and splendor includes Robin Williams deciding in his role to seek out what may or may not be conquerable regarding the experiences of heaven and hell. Normally I don't like extremely serious dramas about very wealthy people who are so successful in life, because of how hard I've worked at it myself and just never have found open doors for me. But I couldn't help getting caught up in this film because in my heart I still hope for that kind of love, that kind of commitment to be reciprocated in a loving relationship, and this film does a super job of challenging my attention and some of the elements of the writer's imagination are simply put, fascinating beyond anything I had seen before I viewed this film. It came out almost 12 years ago, but the special effects and depth of entertainment would be just as well received today. The casting is excellent, the sets are excellent, and I recommend this film 100%. I have watched this film as often as any I own, and still can't get tired of viewing it.

First of all let me say that this movie is HARD to watch. It starts out with tragedy and takes a very long time to swoop out of it - in the end it is an uplifting movie, and amazingly crafted both visually and philosophically - but for the majority of the movie it grips you hard by your emotional core and doesn't let go.
The visual style is incredible, the special effects way ahead of their time, and a take on both cinematic presentation and the afterlife unlike any I've ever seen before.

It can be at times a little heavy-handed and overly serious, but with both incredibly strong performances across the board and a deeply compelling story. This movie definitely goes high on my list as a little-known must see movie.

I remembered seeing the previews for this movie before it come out in the theaters. I was thinking about how colorful and magical it seemed.
I didn't see it in the theater but finally saw it on DVD when it came out.  Yes, this movie is so vividly colorful and amazing.
But on the flip side, it is profoundly sad and gut-wrenching too. I ended up having to stop watching it half-way through and come back to finish
watching it a few hours later.

One thing that bothered me though was the discontinuous story-line. It was often hard to follow as the story seemed to jump around chronologically
and some of the situations were confusing and unclear.

But all in all, I did like the movie and found it amazing to watch. I would recommend it. I think its a good example of "love conquers all" even through
heaven and hell and the afterlife.

First and foremost, if you are interested in Samkhya Philosophy / Yogic self-cultivation and death and dying, this film was pretty much made for you.  If not, you may be disappointed.  Please do a modicum of research on this topic before watching as it will make the entire premise of the film more understandable.  For example, you'll notice that no one knows who or what God is at this stage, which just follows suit with the philosophy.  Divine interaction in the afterlife occurs more intimately at the karana and parusha realms.  I my opinion, this film follows the philosophy to a T, so in this sense I think the movie is spot on.  I get the feeling that many reviewed this move projecting values upon it that were never there in the first place.

My biggest concern with this movie is that the casting is absolutely horrible.  I mean just awful!  To boot, the writing seemed just sorta tossed together.  It's as if they had this great idea and nifty special effects, but then just figured that if they got a big name star, the rest would just take care of itself.  Well, it didn't.

Robin Williams plays a static, overly impulsive and stubborn man who seems to spout useless clichs whenever given the chance.  His daughter is pretty much stoic and his son seems a bit out of his league.  The only believable character is his wife.  As I'm not a big fan of Cuba Gooding jr. I don't feel my commentary on his lack-luster and spastic performance is very meaningful.

Without getting too much into the plot, how the after life functions seems right on.  In the film, Williams is met by a spirit guide, allowed to make his peace with this life and then move on to the astral dimension where imagination and creativity reign.  As we find out, he's not very good at it at first.  Also, the view on personal hell is spot on in my book too.  Some of the more broad metaphysical assumption seem a little contrived, like the whole needing a guide to find someone, seemed a little forced, but it added to the plot a bit.

I'll give this film a four stars as I feel that it followed its own philosophy quite well and because I feel it to be good when alternative (pronounced, "non-Christian") views of the afterlife are made accessible to the public.  I'm still on the fence about giving it three due to the terrible acting and script, but the visual beauty of some scenes seals the deal at four.

...that's the simplest that I can describe this film, which has become very dear to me.  It's a story about two people who find each other while on vacation and discover they are soulmates. They eventually marry and have children, and eventually lose those children to a tragic accident. Not exactly a spoiler here, as we fast-forward into the future about 10-13 years when the children are in junior high and high school. But when Chris, magnificently portrayed by Robin Williams, is killed in a tragic accident himself four years after that devastating accident, it leaves a shattered Annie (Annabella Sciorra) behind, all alone and fragile. In a nutshell, she attempts to find solace in suicide, but this act of desperation and despair leaves her forever inaccessible to her family and Heaven, or so one would think... And I'll leave it at that.
Don't look for religious overtones here, as some of the themes depicted may not coincide with your own views. Regardless, it is still a beautiful story; it was when Matheson wrote it, and it was given a new vibrancy with the motion picture. I am anxiously awaiting the Blu-ray version, whenever that may come...

This is one of my most favorite movies of all time.  When I first saw in the theaters, I had to see it again and again. Years after the death of his two children, a man (Robin Williams) dies and goes to Heaven.  Bereft in her solitude, his wife (Annabella Sciorra) commits suicide and goes to Hell.  The loving husband risks all to rescue his soulmate from eternal damnation.

Director Vincent Ward's film marries visual spectacle to intense personal drama in a manner rarely equaled in film.  The afterlife in this film is mutable and responsive to the thoughts and dreams of its inhabitants, providing many opportunities for magnificent images, and the crew is up to the challenge.  Williams, Sciorra, and the rest of the talented cast provide the emotional core.
Not what I expected.  Lots of sensationalism.  Not the spiritual movie I had been led to believe it was.

Be sure to have a high definition TV to watch this stunningly beautiful rendition of a tragic but beautiful love story.  The pallet of colors is breathtaking and the story moved me.  Have a few tissues available because it touches on many of the most heart-felt emotions imaginable.

This film won the Academy Award for Best Visual Effects and it is the vision of director Vincent Ward of a possible view of life after death.  It challenges us to think of possibilities while also dealing with our humanness as well as our spirituality.  I thoroughly enjoyed this film with Robin Williams, Cuba Gooding, Jr. and Annabella Sciorra!

My wife and I love this film. For me, it is one of the few films I've seen that improves on its literary source (which I also enjoyed) -- the story is considerably tighter, the dramatic tension higher. Williams, Gooding, and Sciorra are uniformly excellent; in fact, this is probably our favorite Robin Williams performance, and that's saying something. Very, very good special effects for the time.

Death, and life after death, are tough subjects, and most people shy away from them, outside the horror or tragedy genres. This film (and its source novel) tackles contemporary afterlife research head on, and provide a moving, emotionally charged experience for those who are open to it.

There are not many works of art that propel and sadden me in the way this film did. Disclaimer: I despise tragic movies; there is enough tragedy in the world for the film industry to not add to it any further. However, What Dreams May Come is a tragedy that helped me center my understandings of true love.

Several friends recommended I view the movie, but I was relunctant to because of the heavy subject matter. I began the movie disgruntled that the tragedy occured so soon; I misperceived initially that it would be about this guy coping with his wife's unfortunate death.

Fortunately, I was wrong. Instead, the next hour and a half revealed the meat that could lay behind the terms "soulmates", "destiny", and "linked hearts" when the intimate connection between two people is true. I finished the movie with tear-stained cheeks, a half-smile, and the irreducible belief that there are spaces where true love persosts.

Now, regardless of the warnings of others, my embattled psyche, and the hopelessness that so often surrounds us in a cultured mired by pessimism, I believe in love.

I will be perfectly honest ... with myself.
I am a huge fan of Robin Williams' work, and I found him sympathetic enough that I found a kind of chemistry between the characters of Christy and Annie that was deeper than on-screen sexual destiny.  I completely bought into the more mature and engaging chemistry of two people who have shared some of the most important, most wonderful, and most painful experiences life can offer.  Add to this that the actors who play the children are gifted in bringing us around to liking them and being concerned over what bothers them.  There are only two role left, well, one actually...but I don't want to ruin that little tweak.  Suffice it to say that I am ever impressed by Cuba Gooding, Jr's emotional range and depth and his remarkable ability to share his outstanding interpretation of his character with us, and as for Max Von Sydow?  Who else can be so charming, strong, fatherly, and somehow frightening all at once?  For many of us, he will ever be the iconic "old priest" -- Father Merin from a little movie that never quite gives up its hold on #1 on the list of scariest movies ever made.

So that's the technical stuff.  Now for the honesty.

It is possible that this film is emotionally manipulative, and I know some critics that denounce such exhibits of film making prowess as "cheesy," "predictable," and "pushy."  Twenty years ago, Robin starred in another emo machine called Dead Poets Society.  Again, critics who have not the talent to elicit more than cynicism panned the film because it succeeded in creating an emotional response.  Tell me Romeo & Juliet is anything but a calculated tear-jerker.  Shall we give Shakespeare one star?  So what's it all add up to?  Simply this honest statement:  I've not cried at a film like this since Dead Poets.  That film I cried at as a child beginning his first year of teaching.  This one I cried with as an adult who better  understands something of loss, regret, and never giving up.

First, let me say that I've always had a fndness for Robin Williams' films. OK, he's sometimes schmaltzy, but for a long time he was only given schmaltzy and/or cartoonish roles. What did anyone expect? People who are still biased against him might want to check out his later work.

Anyway. I recently tuned into this film out of idle curiosity, and found myself completely mesmerized by the highly saturated colors and pretty realistic visual effects used in the film. I have to say that color and visual texture are some of my favorite things in movies; watching a richly-shaded film like "Girl With a Pearl Earring" is, for me, to experience two hours of pure visceral delight.

I really didn't care too much about what the film had to say about the living and the dead. But I tend not to get my philosophies from movies.

A film critic once called the film "Barry Lyndon" "a feast for the eyes, a famine for the mind." And some may say the same of "What Dreams May Come," which at least is not hobbled by the wretched excesses of Stanley Kubrick's self-indulgent direction. But all the same, beauty should be celebrated. Too little of it comes out of Hollywood these days.

This film does what the final sequence in 2001: A Space Odyssey failed to do: inspire simple awe in the beauty that is possible.
This is one of my favorite movies. I highly recommend it to anyone that is looking for humor, suspense, and a great love story.

What Dreams May Come is a great movie that touches on possible aspects of what may follow after death. It posits that there may indeed be a reality, however counter-intuitive, of life after death. This movie is based on the book writen in the 70s. Some may consider the book better than the movie, but as a person who has read the book too, I would not necessarily say that. I think the book is also very good, but at the same time I just think that the book and movie are just different ways of portraying the same subject. Some of the themes and elements are the same, even though the book goes into far more details on the subject.

I just think that the book and movie are both very good, but they are also very different. One is not necessarily better than the other, but the movie rendition of the book, while not an exact replica of the story therein, is a very good rendition. This movie won an Oscar, so that should tell all about how great this motion picture experience really is.

Robin Williams, Cuba Gooding Jr. and Max Von Sidow all do absolutely excellent acting jobs. The special effects are dazzling and tremendous! The concepts about life after death are also very thought provoking. In fact, these concepts are based on alledged facts that Richard Matheson himself uncovered doing research for his book. Even on the front piece of the book he mentions that the research on the subject of life after death in his story is solid and accurate, even though the story itself is fictional account that is woven around the theory of life after death.

For anyone with an open mind and/or has any concerns or interests in what may indeed be the fate of us all after death, I highly recommend this very telling tale. The story is sometimes shocking, sometimes happy and sometimes very sad. But overall I don't think anyone seeing this movie will be disappointed in it whatsoever. I think most people will be pleasantly surprised by the story and special effects and the intellectual stimulation they may get out of watching this film.

5 stars!

Before I wrote this, I read around a few of the other posted reviews here and at the IMDB,( Internet Movie Database ) and what I read surprised me. Example, I would feel much different viewing the loss of children perhaps if I wasn't a parent myself, and could agonize with the uncomprehensible loss of a child, for me events like that have impact. The loss of your own life in the middle of busy life events due to a split second tragedy, leaving those behind crazy for your loss...and the guilt you would feel if you could experience what your death did to the lives of the ones you leave behind.
